caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Artoria ligulacea ( Qu, Peng & Yin, 2009 )
, A. Male habitus, dorsal view; B. Female habitus, dorsal view; C. Male eyes and chelicerae, front view; D. Left male pedipalp, ventral view; E. Same, retrolateral view; F. Apical part of bulb, ventral view; G. Epigyne, ventral view; H. Female internal genitalia, dorsal view.

FIGURE 9.
Artoria parvula Thorell, 1877
, A. Left male pedipalp, ventral view; B. Same, retrolateral view; C. Apical part of bulb, ventral view; D. Epigyne, ventral view; E. Female internal genitalia, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species resembles
A . ligulacea ( Qu, Peng & Yin, 2009 )
( Figs 7â€“8 ), but can be distinguished from the latter by the distal end of median apophysis triangular, with ventrally bent tip ( Figs 9Aâ€“B , 10Dâ€“E ), whereas it is similar to the head of a cobra snake in
A . ligulacea
( Figs 7Aâ€“B , 8Dâ€“E ), basoembolic apophysis almost round and not sclerotized ( Figs 9A, C , 10Dâ€“F ), whereas longer than wide, highly sclerotized in
A . ligulacea
( Figs 7A, C , 8D, F ). Posterior margin of epigyne with a depression ( Figs 9Dâ€“E , 10Gâ€“H ), whereas posterior margin straight in
A . ligulacea
( Figs 7Dâ€“E , 8Gâ€“H ). Spermathecal head furcated into two branches ( Figs 9E , 10H ), whereas not furcated in
A . ligulacea
( Figs 7E , 8H ).

Description. See
Li et al. (2012)
for both sexes. Habitus, male pedipalp, and epigyne as in Figs 9â€“10 .
